thread.title: Suburban Catholic high schools draw students from China - Elm Leaves
thread.title_full: Suburban Catholic high schools draw students from China - Elm Leaves

author: David Pollard
title: Suburban Catholic high schools draw students from China - Elm Leaves
text:
Many high school students head home once class lets out for the day, but for a few students at Guerin Prep High School, their homes are thousands of miles away.
Nearly two dozen students from China left their homes and families behind to study in the United States, and some have enrolled at Guerin Prep High School in River Grove.
The students were able to take advantage of this opportunity through the Greater Chicago International Academy, which offers international students the chance to attend high quality high school programs in Chicago and surrounding cities.
Jian-Guo Sun, president and founder of the academy, started the program in Milwaukee in 2012. Studying at universities and colleges in the United States has been a draw for international students and Sun has taken it one step further, providing an opportunity for Chinese students to study abroad at the high school level.
For an annual fee of $40,000, his program places Chinese students at a faith-based high school in the Chicago area.
Derek Zhang, 19, and Christine Li, 15, currently attend Guerin Prep through the Greater Chicago International Academy. Zhang is a junior and Li is a sophomore at the school. They're two of 20 students attending high schools in the Chicagoland area.
Both say they've enjoyed their experience so far.
"There's more free time to do the things that we love to do," Li said. "I'm on the cross country team and I also play piano."
Zhang is on the tennis team and enjoys playing golf. He said he sometimes misses home and his parents â€” but not enough to go back.
"I'll graduate in 2016 and I will choose a college in Chicago, and stay here in Chicago and major in international business and hotel management," Zhang said.
Sun said the students are happy to be here.
"The kids aren't homesick at all," he said. "It's the parents who miss the kids."
Sun said students who attend school in the area stay at the Write Inn Hotel in Oak Park and are driven to and from school. They are supervised at the hotel by Greater Chicago International Academy staff, who also provide tutoring and extracurricular activities outside of school.
The immersion in the American culture improves their English language skills and helps them with the standardized tests they will take in the future.
Sun said while students are under the academy's supervision, staff and personnel act as their family and home away from home.
"We treat them like adults, talk to them like adults, hold them accountable and give them respect," Sun said. "Treat them well and they will treat you well."
